| Italian | Derived | Etymology | |---|---|---| | poi | Latin | post | | appresso | Latin | apud + pressus | | con | Latin | cum | | il | Latin | ille | | occhio | Latin | oculus | | più | Latin | plus | | accendere | Latin | ad + candere | | il | Latin | ille | | benedetto | Latin | benedictus | | segno | Latin | signum | | io | Latin | ego | | rispondere | Latin | re + spondere | | per | Latin | per | | non | Latin | non | | tenere | Latin | tenere | | in | Latin | in | | ammirare | Latin | ad + mirari | | sospendere | Latin | sus + pendere |
**Note:**
* The etymology of "poi" is uncertain, but it may be derived from the Latin "post" (after). * The etymology of "appresso" is from the Latin "apud" (near) and "pressus" (pressed). * The etymology of "con" is from the Latin "cum" (with). * The etymology of "occhio" is from the Latin "oculus" (eye). * The etymology of "più" is from the Latin "plus" (more). * The etymology of "accendere" is from the Latin "ad" (to) and "candere" (to shine). * The etymology of "benedetto" is from the Latin "benedictus" (blessed). * The etymology of "segno" is from the Latin "signum" (sign). * The etymology of "io" is from the Latin "ego" (I). * The etymology of "rispondere" is from the Latin "re" (back) and "spondere" (to promise). * The etymology of "per" is from the Latin "per" (through). * The etymology of "non" is from the Latin "non" (not). * The etymology of "tenere" is from the Latin "tenere" (to hold). * The etymology of "in" is from the Latin "in" (in). * The etymology of "ammirare" is from the Latin "ad" (to) and "mirari" (to wonder at). * The etymology of "sospendere" is from the Latin "sus" (up) and "pendere" (to hang).

**Unknown etymology:**
* scemo
**Note:**
* The word "dolce" comes from the Latin word "dulcis," which means "sweet." However, the Italian word "dolce" can also mean "soft" or "gentle." * The word "così" comes from the Latin phrase "ecce sic," which means "behold, thus." * The word "fare" comes from the Latin word "facere," which means "to do" or "to make." * The word "perché" comes from the Latin phrase "per quid," which means "for what reason?" * The word "affinare" comes from the Latin phrase "ad finire," which means "to bring to an end."
